‘What’s next for you?’ she shouted, jumping up. Her tear-filled eyes suddenly sparkled. ‘Stand up!’ (She grabbed his shoulder; he stood, looking confused.) ‘Right now, go to the crossroads. Bow down, kiss the ground you’ve dirtied, and shout to everyone, “I am a murderer!” Then God will give you life again. Will you do it? Will you?’ She was shaking, holding his hands tightly, her gaze intense. 

He was taken aback by her sudden passion.  
‘You mean I should go to Siberia, Sonia? Give myself up?’ he asked gloomily.  
‘You need to suffer and make up for your sin,’ she insisted.  
‘No! I’m not going to them, Sonia!’  
‘But how can you keep living? What’s your reason now?’ Sonia cried. ‘How can you even face your mom? (What will happen to them now?) But wait, you’ve already abandoned your mom and sister! Oh, God!’ she exclaimed. ‘He knows it all. How can he live with himself? What will happen to you?’  
‘Don’t be naive, Sonia,’ he replied gently. ‘What have I done to them? Why should I go? What would I even say? That’s just a ghost… They ruin lives by the millions and think it’s good. They’re the real scoundrels, Sonia! I’m not going to them.’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Sonia urges Raskolnikov to confess his crime and seek redemption, but he resists, questioning the value of doing so.
